question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In Dr. Charmaine Royal's Race, Genomics, and Society course, I developed a deeper understanding of how race, though a social construct, significantly impacts scientific research and healthcare. I learned to critically evaluate the use of racial categories in genomic studies and how they can perpetuate harmful stereotypes rather than address health disparities. The course also emphasized the importance of open communication and respectful discussion, allowing me to listen to and consider different perspectives with an open mind. Additionally, I gained insights into how race intersects with other identities, such as gender and socioeconomic status, to shape health outcomes, reinforcing the need for culturally competent care. These lessons have fostered a socially conscious and ethical approach to addressing systemic inequities in science and healthcare.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my study skills and the ability to write under pressure (during the exams). Improved collaborative skills and how to facilitate empowering and respectful discussions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The specific science behind why race is not biological in humans, and the history of how race developed in America, and other countries. Also learned the impact socially defined race has on perceptions and life outcomes in America and different countries, such as Brazil.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The biggest take away from the class being that there is no biological race with the human race. The way in which we conceive race is a social construct based on a hierarchy. Humans are 99.6% genetically similar.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: participation, creative project documentary creation, and literature review

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I felt like this class was very lecture-based with not much writing, but our final project culminated in producing a documentary, which I learned useful skills from regarding collecting data, working with my discussion section/production team, and having conversations with people about very widely debated/misconceived ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about race as a social versus biological construct. Learned to think about the history of race and racism in a contextual and thorough way. Learned about genetics, intelligence and athletic ability.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel equipped with the tools and evidence to explain to others why race is not a biological concept. I have come to understand that lived experiences of individuals are shaped by genetic and environmental factors. Our final creative projects provided me with insight on how to facilitiate productive conversations about race, genomics, and society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This being a multidisciplinary course, we learned about many, many things. We learned the genetic basis of biological race (and the lack thereof in humans - i.e., we learned *why* humans don't have biological race); we learned about genetic ancestry, genomics, and so on; we learned about the social context of these scientific 'developments' (eugenics, profit, oppression, etc.); we learned about the fundamental theory of oppression.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the biological basis of race in humans, or lack thereof. I learned more about race, racial hierarchies, etc., in a global context. I learned about genetic testing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to separate biological and social concepts when looking at racial topics. I also understood the history behind what the modern understanding of race was. Finally, I found what it means to have different aspects of your identity and how that intersects with your biological makeup.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class provides an understanding of how scientific and genomic theories have contributed to the development of systemic racism. Discussions about historical events like Bacon's Rebellion, modern debates like race-based medicines such as BiDil, and about our understanding of race and racism and the factors informing it were incredibly engaging. The work we were doing felt important to learn about and discuss.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this class about how to work with a group, forming thoughts and structuring cohesive arguments, and the biological and social implications of race

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Charmaine Royal created an engaging and inclusive learning environment that fostered critical thinking and thoughtful discussion. Her emphasis on open dialogue encouraged students to share diverse perspectives, which enriched our understanding of complex topics related to race and genomics. One of the most impactful components of the course was the discussions where we shared our personal experiences and thoughts in a respectful, open space. These conversations allowed us to learn from one another and connect course material to real-life contexts, deepening our understanding of the social implications of genomics. The use of case studies and real-world examples also made the material more relatable and demonstrated the real-life consequences of the issues we studied. For future years, I would recommend keeping these interactive discussions, as they were instrumental in facilitating meaningful learning and fostering a supportive classroom community.

To make the course even more stimulating, incorporating more hands-on activities or projects that connect course concepts to current events or community issues could further enhance intellectual engagement.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking Race, Genomics, and Society, I highly recommend it. This course offers a unique and thought-provoking perspective on how race intersects with science, especially genomics, and its implications for healthcare and society. Dr. Charmaine Royal fosters a respectful and open environment where you can engage in deep discussions, challenge assumptions, and explore the ethical dimensions of scientific research. The readings and case studies are compelling and relevant, pushing you to think critically about the role of race in shaping health outcomes and scientific practices. Additionally, the course includes distinguished guest speakers, providing valuable real-world perspectives. Be prepared to reflect, engage in meaningful conversations, and develop a more nuanced understanding of race and science. It’s a course that will not only broaden your knowledge but also inspire you to think differently about issues of social justice and equity.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
There are a lot of readings, and it is easy to fall behind. While the readings are discussed in class, if you don't necessarily get to all of them before class, you will probably be okay. Sometimes I found it more helpful to read or reread things after class gave me an overview of the topic they went in-depth on. 
Also, attendance and participation is technically mandatory, but there is a little wiggle room.  You can have 3 class absences and 2 discussion absences with no issue, and they seem to be somewhat lenient on participation; so long as you try to engage with the course, it will probably be okay.
This is a no-tech class.

response_text: Learned how to discuss ethical dilemmas within the biomedical field. The primary piece was creating a basis for how to discuss ethical issues through four key principles. We then focused on the fields of machine learning and artificial intelligence, organoids, gene editing, and brain-computer interfaces throughout the year.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Ethical and philosophical frameworks that govern biomedical ethics, and learning about the four technologies themselves too (gene editing, organoids, BCI, AI/ML)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got more comfortable writing a long paper with context and argument. I heard ethical debates with regard to science that I hadn't considered before. I got better at articulating arguments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I deepened my understanding of bioethics beyond just the four bioethical principles. We talked extensively about autonomy, beneficence, non-maleficence, and justice. Every week, we talked the ethical implications as it related to different topics such as somatic and germline editing, BCIs, and stem cell research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I experienced a lot of development in my writing pertaining biomedical ethics. It's been a while, so this class really helped me with regards to writing longer essay assignments and making sure I incorporated sources with purpose. I also gained a lot of insight on the current standing of up-and-coming biomedical technologies as well as ethical concerns that we need to address in our pursuit of such technologies. Overall, the course was extremely helpful and I find myself thinking about the ethics of BME in my spare time often.

response_text:

- writing argumentative and perspectives essays
- writing short reflection papers based on course content

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are an engineer coming into this course, be prepared for heavy amounts of reading and writing. The readings can range from dense technical information about how technologies you will discuss in class to ethical arguments about such technologies. The ethics-focused readings, while still equally dense at times, are usually still interesting as they tackle opinions on the use of the technologies. There's also a substantial writing portion to the class. This consists of ~400-word recaps every other week related to what you discussed in class to two ~4000-word essays right before spring break and then the week before LDOC.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that "natural" disasters are not natural, and that humans have been changing our environment, and now we are feeling the effects. I learned that different disasters like terrorism, tsunamis, or hurricanes are all connected at a deeper level, and different people experience these events in different ways. Finally, I learned about different policies and companies that contribute to these tragedies and how to alter community organizing in the future to help stop climate change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned to expand my definition of disability outside of the medical model, which is very essentialist.
Additionally, I was challenged to expand my definition of "care" and look critically at how these structures are often interconnected with lack of action by the state, and how this factors into disability studies. 
Finally, I learned about the words "disability" and "impairment" and how those in either community choose to use (or not use) these terms for specific reasons.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This is the first course I have taken in Disability Studies and it was, needless to say, a fantastic introduction. Emily was an incredible professor whose knowledge, passion, humor, and enthusiasm made the class wonderful. I learned a lot throughout the course including the general models of disability, the ways in which capitalism and work intersect with disability, and the extent to which disability appears and is recognized, understood, perceived, etc. in society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me about different models and ways of viewing disability, such as the social model. We also learned about the history of disability and how capitalism has played into understandings and definitions of what it means to be disabled. Finally, we learned to think about disability in ways that allow us to apply these frameworks to other situations in the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
My view of disability and the idea of how bodies are a part of societal systems related to work (and the toll taken on bodies as value is extracted from them) was novel, and changed my worldview in a lot of things. 
1. Neoliberalism and how it puts a focus on individuals 
2. How external conditions can cause disability (like gangs) 
3. Cultural/shared disability was very interesting, especially when in the context of the Gaza conflict

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the different models of disability, I learned about disability in relation to capitalism, and I learned how to critically evaluate ethnographies, historical texts, narratives/creative works, etc in the context of our class

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Denis is fantastic! Not only is he incredibly knowledgeable, but he also brings a wealth of experience and insight to the class. His ability to connect theoretical concepts with real-world applications makes the material engaging and relevant. He encourages thoughtful discussions and challenges students to think critically, creating a stimulating and supportive learning environment. You will get a thorough understanding of China's science and technology policies, focusing on real-world challenges and innovations. The multidisciplinary approach helps you connect political economy, technology, and global relations. With rich case studies, interactive discussions, and high-quality readings, it fosters critical thinking and practical knowledge. This course is perfect for students interested in global innovation dynamics, China's technological rise, or the intersection of policy and science. And, Professor Simon is definitely the one to guide you through this complex and fascinating subject. His passion for the topic and dedication to his students make the learning experience truly exceptional. If you want to gain a deep understanding of China's innovation strategies and their global impact, this course, led by Professor Denis Simon, is an opportunity you shouldn’t miss.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned how there are a multitude of stories behind language, terminology, and our understanding of the environment. 
2. The origin of colonialism and the anthropocene, and how this history shapes our modern outlooks on the environment and environmental justice. (Example - reviewing the influence of darwinism and what is "natural" and "just", etc.)
3. Narratives matter, and there are many of them. The differences between writers such as Locke, Darwin, Thoreau, Simmard, Kimmerer, Marsh, and more are astounding and reflect different understandings of the right of humans to take from this Earth and ultimately what the consequences of this become. These highlight how environmental issues cannot be divorced from questions of power, ethics, and equity. These different narratives allows us to evaluate historical paradigms (like commodification of nature) in context of the issues of today. These narratives show that environmental justice is not a single story and its ever-evolving to include and prioritize different ecological and social living systems. 
4. Environmental justice is not just about nature or wilderness. It's not just about economic opportunity. It's everything that surrounds us. It's about recognizing the right of everyone and everything, and the impact it leaves on everything else. It's about recognizing marginalized communities and preservation of spaces. It's about policymaking that reflects a commitment to the well-being of all things, as all things are interrelated. It shows the interconnected framework that integrates social equity, ecological health, and the well-being of all living systems. Environmental justice transcends any single issue. At its core, environmental justice is about reimagining the boundaries of "us"/"them"/"we" and instead honoring the reciprocity that must come with our globe through shared responsibility.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about Duke with new context of its history within Durham. I also learned about how to think about ameliorating the environmental burdens of certain communities. For example, we spent a class using Beaufort as a case study of towns where environmental injustices have occurred, and we brainstormed ways that things could have done differently and we looked at all of the factors involved in both creating and solving the problem

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1. The history of race in Durham
2. Darwin's influence on the world around him
3. How to break down a case study in which one discourse is told that does not reflect the true history and identity of a location and the strategies we can use to prevent this breakdown.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how storytelling and the political interact; how structural violence affects the way Durham looks; and how different philosophers and thinkers view uncultivated and cultivated land.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I LOVED THIS CLASS. One of my favorites at Duke, and Dr. Priscilla Wald was the reason for this. She guides the class effectively while also letting the class flow when my peers and I were discussing related things. For example, the day after the election was solely a time to reflect and she let us talk about whatever we wanted instead of "having" to do the exercises associated with the readings for that day. I also particularly loved that the class was outside most of the time in the gardens and around Duke/Durham. Keep all methods of instruction. I can't say enough how much I loved this class and the hospitable environment we had. She also gave us opportunities to work on creative pieces without any reprecussions, and discussion posts had no particular guidelines we had to follow.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved having class in the gardens. I would definitely keep the field trip components. I would also keep the open class structure. This is the first class that I've been in that was able to facilitate such effective open communication. Breaking off into small groups and then reporting back ensured that everyone was involved in the discussion and made the discussion feel very casual. I think that this format, as well as sitting outside in a circle, helped everyone feel able and willing to contribute. Finally, I loved that we were able to adjust the schedule to take time to discuss stressful current events.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I was a bit scared, since I do not consider myself a humanities person, and I do not write a lot. However, this course, and Liz Apple, was able to push me and teach me to share thoughts and write both a reseach and creative paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
In this course, I developed a more holistic understanding of medicine, moving beyond the rigid, science-focused perspective that dominates most of my other studies. I learned to view medicine through the lens of the humanities, realizing that understanding human experiences of illness, suffering, and healing requires more than just scientific knowledge. The course taught me that literature and the arts offer essential tools for developing empathy, which is critical in patient care. They not only foster compassion but also enhance our imagination and critical thinking, which are vital when dealing with complex or unconventional medical situations, such as in military settings. This expanded perspective has made me believe that the humanities are as crucial to medical practice as the hard sciences, helping us navigate the emotional and relational aspects of patient care that science alone cannot explain.
Additionally, the course sharpened my analytical skills and taught me the importance of engaging critically with materials. Instead of passively accepting the views presented in texts or media, I learned to question assumptions, contrast perspectives with my own medical experiences, and think critically about the information at hand. This skill has become especially valuable in a world where misinformation is rampant. Moreover, the course provided a unique collaborative learning environment, where I not only learned from the professor but also from my classmates, whose diverse backgrounds and experiences enriched my understanding of the material. Through this, I developed a deeper ability to listen carefully and empathetically, a skill that will be indispensable in my medical practice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment of this class was shaped significantly by both the course structure and, more importantly, by Professor Apple’s teaching style. One component that stood out to me was the keyword readings, which were especially practical for understanding key concepts in medicine. Terms like “patient” were dissected in a way that revealed their complexity and depth, encouraging us to think critically about language and its implications in healthcare. These readings were invaluable in challenging our preconceived notions and reshaping the way we think about medical practice. The active class discussions that followed these readings further enriched my understanding. Engaging with peers in dialogue, guided by Professor Apple’s expertise, allowed us to explore various interpretations of the texts, connecting them to our own experiences in medicine. I think future iterations of the course could benefit from a balanced approach, perhaps a 50/50 split between didactic lectures and discussions. Having more time dedicated to exploring scholarly perspectives and Professor Apple’s own insights on the texts would be a great way to deepen our analysis and understanding.
However, the structure and components of the course were only part of what made it truly exceptional. Above all, it was Professor Apple’s character and teaching style that created a learning environment where I felt both intellectually challenged and personally inspired. Her positive attitude, enthusiasm, and the respect she showed for each student fostered a space of genuine curiosity and open dialogue. More than just teaching the course content, Professor Apple embodied the qualities of a compassionate, thoughtful, and ethical physician, and I learned just as much from her personal example as I did from the readings. A friend of mine from another university who sat in with me on one of her classes remarked that it was unlike any class he had ever experienced—highlighting the depth of the discussions and the dynamic group activities that Professor Apple facilitated. This feedback, along with my own experience, underscores her exceptional ability to teach and connect with students. Duke is fortunate to have such a dedicated and insightful instructor, and I believe future students will greatly benefit from the structure, content, and, most importantly, the teacher herself.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
This class was undeniably intellectually stimulating, offering a wealth of thought-provoking material and engaging discussions. One of the most stimulating aspects was the class discussions themselves, where hearing from other students exposed me to perspectives I had not previously considered. These diverse viewpoints challenged my assumptions and expanded my thinking, emphasizing the value of deep listening in truly understanding complex issues. I came to realize that true comprehension does not always stem from agreeing with others, but rather from engaging respectfully and thoughtfully with their ideas. This ability to listen deeply and consider opposing perspectives is a crucial skill, both in medicine and in life.
Beyond the discussions, the readings chosen by Professor Apple were another key element of what made this class so intellectually enriching. The texts were not only thought-provoking but also incredibly relevant, as they delved into aspects of human behavior that are central to understanding the practice of medicine. These readings brought a practical dimension to our exploration, offering insights into how we can better understand and relate to patients, colleagues, and ourselves. They grounded theoretical ideas in real-world scenarios, making the intellectual experience both engaging and applicable. In this way, the course nicely combined rich intellectual content with practical applicability, creating a stimulating learning environment that was both deep and meaningful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Wow. Learned a lot. We started with a pretty fundamental overview of the history behind the philosophy of mind. We started with Descartes, the father of modern philosophy, and moved on from there. Our book, Minds and Computers, concluded with computational theory of mind, which argues that if humans are machines, the brain is basically the hardware and the mind is the software. However, Searle showed us that computationalism can't answer intentionality (formal programs can't constitute understanding), so we have tried to find other theories that may work to explain the mind. Between Heidegger, Wittgenstein, Brentano, Dennet, Hagel, we have come to realize the importance of subjective experience in the world. So far, I really like the embodied mind theory and its appeal to naturalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class helps to develop critical thinking. We go through a lot of ethical delimmas that require complex thinking. It also helps develop our debate skills because a lot of the modules do not have a definitive right or wrong answer. Cultrual sensitivity is also a big component.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed so many skills in this course. I learned how to think about global issues ethically and think of smaller solutions to larger problems. I learned how to challenge opinions and previous research. I learned how to always remain culturally sensitive when talking about and presenting global health issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the ethics of global health media, different ways of evaluating the ethics of a situation, and basic principles associated with global health ethics

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to take into account different perspectives, form an argument, and practice empathy and understanding for different situations people are going through.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about relevant and practical ethical frameworks applicable to my future academic work in Global Health. I gained new skills in case study analysis and debate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: (1) Different ethical theories and frameworks, (2) How to apply these theories/frameworks to different global health issues and case studies, (3) how to synthesize information from films/documentaries, readings, research articles, etc. to create cohesive arguments

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to apply ethical frameworks, cultural competency when doing research and even learning about other cultures/countries, how to approach ethical dilemmas and when to realize there is no right way-- then in that case, how to apply own moral code

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about ethical frameworks and how to think through case studies through different ethical frameworks. We also learned details of cases such as HIV/AIDS in Cuba, the Ebola Quarantine in Liberia, and the Havasupai diabetes research case.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Knowledge of infectious diseases that I previously didn't even know existed
- Many new frameworks for how to think ethically about Global Health topics
- How to debate both sides of an ethical dilemma

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a great deal about ethical research within the context of global health. I didn’t realize how much research had unethical practices before this class, so it is nice to learn more.  I believe this class also made me better at group work because a majority of our assignments were with a group. Additionally, I believe this course helped me improve in writing concisely because the class quizzes were open answer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never taken an ethics of philosophy course before so a lot of the readings and methods of analysis were new to me. One thing that stood out to me that I learned in this course was how to deal with ambiguity. Ethical codes and applications are subject to different interpretations and there is more often than not no right answer. Additionally, this course developed my ability to analyze situations from a variety of perspectives while taking into account the motivations and concerns of different stakeholders.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-what Ebola looked like in the US at the height of Ebola outbreaks in Africa
-principilism and how its core ethical principles can be applied to all different types of ethical situations
-the difference between ethics for bioethics vs humanitarian/social work vs clinical physicians vs public health

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of ethical principles, frameworks, and skills in applying these frameworks to real case studies. I think this course is very meaningful for me, as I have never systematically learned about the ethics in global health. The class activities also include debates, and simulations that enable me to further think about the stakeholders and their perspectives when facing an ethical dilemma.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned an enormous amount about how to approach ethical issues with infectious diseases and also how the characteristics of those diseases affect ethical issues. I learned about this in the context of HIV quarantine in Cuba, the implications of researching Kuru in Papua New Guinea, and how the San people in South Africa created their own ethical framework for researchers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about the ethics of infectious disease, photo ethics, and the responsibility a researcher has to the community they are researching.

response_text: Dr. Stewart split the class time very well. She lectured for half, and the other half was either time to work on a group presentation about the ethics of the case study we are discussing that week or a film to further our knowledge on the case study. I would also continue with the hybrid lecture-work/presentation format. It allowed us to have different dynamics so that we weren't only sitting in a lecture for an 1hr 15 minutes. I also think it is very helpful to have the quiz grades increase incrementally up until quiz 4. I think that takes a bit of pressure of students for quizzes until they get used to the quiz format/flow.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very reading intensive course and you have to pay attention and take notes when reading. The lecture slides are helpful to guide you, but Dr. Stewart's lectures themselves don't get very far through them. The quizzes are very writing intensive and make up almost your whole grade, and they will shock you at first with the content and quantity. I do think you get used to them over time and grades get better, but if you mess up badly on the first or second quiz, then the whole semester becomes really tough. Definitely a very intense course, so if that's something you want, go for it. You'll learn a lot about ethics, but you will be under pressure for sure.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course has really interesting readings, discussions, films, case studies, etc. However, the quizzes are extremely demanding and time consuming to prepare for, they feel like midterms every single time, and they occur quite frequently for the first 2/3 of the course. Be prepared to take a lot of time out of your schedule to prepare for the "quizzes" and do not try to take this as you easy or chill class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned how, due to androcentrism, this manifested into thinking that women were strange and attempting to understand them. I also learned more about history that is not traditionally taught in schools, such as the fact that the field of gynecology was able to progress due to the medical torture of Black enslaved women.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the major paradigms for studying the history of science, including normal science/puzzle solving, scientific revolutions, and ideas about progress and its limits. This course covers the whole globe and many different disciplines, concepts, and periods of history, starting with early modern natural philosophy and going up to modern genetics, data science/computing, and pseudoscience. It's a good introduction to a lot of different topics and you talk about something very different pretty much every day.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

It taught me many different ways of thinking about science, stretching from pseudoscience to centuries-old trees of knowledge. I forced me to think critically and also required a bit of recall in different disciplines such as biology and physics.

response_text: I loved Professor Shahrazad's science and the modern world class. If you're worried about workload, this class doesn't really have much! Prof. Shahrazad is also very kind, friendly, and a great teacher who will always clarify if you're confused, and obviously cares about her students. I really love her. She also watches anime which is another pro. Take her class!! I loved it.

2) The interconnectedness of the scientific, religious, and magical fields -- domains I believed to be separate before this class
3) The evolution of the 3 main domains from ancient times to the enlightenment

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

3. allowed me to form my own views on the previously nebulous concepts of magic, science, and religion; allowed me to understand how they relate to each other, where they overlap and where they diverge

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned historical context for how magic, science, and religion developed alongside one another with particular focus on Europe and the United States, I learned tools for how to approach and situate archival resources into wider conversations about historical processes, and I learned about the ways in which centuries-old historical processes are still at play influencing current perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Knowledge: learning words such as "heretical", "automata", "astro-medicine"; Historic movements and contexts related to magic, religion and science. 
Skills: Analyzing rare books and primary materials
Ways of thinking: The shaping of a person's worldview is largely formed by the time and place they are in. The reverence for science has not always been like it is today.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the lectures and I think Prof Boucher does a great job making the long lectures entertaining and interesting. I enjoyed the discussion posts as I think they help students learn, think, and assess their own opinions on topics. I think my favorite part of the class was the group presentations. All the groups picked very interesting healthcare issues and I enjoyed getting to learn about some of the specific topics in our healthcare system that were not covered in class. I also appreciate not having a final. Having tests would change the dynamic of the class. The current structure allows for students to debate about topics, and really think about the endless list of healthcare issues our system has. Having a final or other test would change the dynamic into something that people have to memorize the information instead of analyzing and reflecting upon the topics.

response_text: I think this is a fascinating course, I can really see how it's the starting point for the health policy certificate. It's sad to hear about policies actively working against providing universal health care access, and it's even worse to hear about specific issues we're too powerless to change. Regardless, this course was quite outstanding, both in its material and the professor, and I would certainly recommend it!

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I'd highly recommend this class for anyone who may be interested in health policy or going into a health profession in the future (aka premeds- you should take this course)! It wasn't a whole bunch of work with the way Prof Campbell set up the course. We had weekly reflections, three assignments spread out throughout the semester, and a final project. The weekly reflections took me longer than I initially thought it would (3-5 hours, including reading the assigned articles + writing), but I learned so much.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come to class prepared with things to say about the readings and prepare to steer the discussion. If there is something you would like to get out of the class, make that clear. Dr. Campbell was very open-minded and open to feedback.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was a great introduction to the US healthcare system, with complex topics and debates ranging from abortion to healthcare insurance coverage. We discussed the dominance of employer-sponsored insurance and US health spend compared globally. I would recommend the course to anyone interested in health policy, community health, and medicine!

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.

response_text: This course is very interesting and manageable for students of all majors. It provides a lot of insight into how healthcare works in the US particularly, but also in a more general sense. It has been helpful in shaping my understanding of how things like insurance, quality of care etc are managed, which I think are important and applicable to the near future when I have to make health decisions for myself.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write better argumentative essays by thinking about counterarguments and poking holes in it to bring back the point. I learned how biases present themselves in studies. I learned about the U.S. healthcare landscape and the many factors that have influenced its becoming.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to put my own personal beliefs aside and write objectively, even if I did not agree with the stance I was taking. I also learned about the various considerations that go into policy decisions and that it will be much more difficult to reform healthcare than I previous thought.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed an ability to critically weigh benefits and drawbacks of the American healthcare system, and to evaluate my ideas with sufficient rigor. The latter point was an emphasis of the class, which I greatly appreciated as I potentially consider a career in health policy.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Dr. Ubel's style of "cold calling" students in class helped me to think on me feet, stay engaged, allow my opinions and ideas to be challenged, and use critical thinking skills. Additionally, the "impossible to answer" essay prompts made me think more broadly and precisely.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think about the US healthcare system. We did this through readings, quizzes, and essays, as well as in class participation. I learned numerous insights into just how complicated the US healthcare system truly is, and how it converges with the field of economics. We studied cost, quality, and access extensively, and critically evaluated what aspects should be tackled in order to fix a flawed system.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the US healthcare system and its pros and cons. The essays make you question what you think is true and then decide how to best refute opposing views. I learned to be much more critical of what our current systems in place are and that even though the US is doing something does not make it the right thing to do. I also learned to concisely get points across, especially when the topics can be hard to discuss.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.

response_text:
-- Knowledge about the basic structures of the US healthcare system, including private insurers, CMS, drug manufacturers/pharmacies/PBMs, etc. Some comparison to other countries
-- How incentives modify the behavior of patients, physicians, hospitals, insurers, and so on 
-- Various payment systemts, attempted reforms, and ongoing research into future models of health care

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that "natural" disasters are not natural, and that humans have been changing our environment, and now we are feeling the effects. I learned that different disasters like terrorism, tsunamis, or hurricanes are all connected at a deeper level, and different people experience these events in different ways. Finally, I learned about different policies and companies that contribute to these tragedies and how to alter community organizing in the future to help stop climate change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- learned about cultural anthropology

- wrote a research paper

response_text: I learned a lot about climate crises.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: critical thinking, reading, literature analysis, discussion, and active listening skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My knowledge about how we, as a society, view climate change and the following environmental disasters has grown more nuanced. The insights into the effects of disasters on devastating human lives is new.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to write an ethnographic paper with a focus on environmental data and analysis techniques
2. Exploring how climate change is portrayed in the media over a period of time, from Katrina to Helene
3. Finding ways to promote climate change solutions by adapting to the audience and their cultural beliefs

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about seeing climate change through perspectives that aren't my own. I learned about Hurricane Helene and Katrina!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to look at issues present outside the basic perspective that comes up first. Examples include the recovery aspect of Hurricane Katrina, and how the government not being supportive was not all you needed to know about the recovery process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of analysis when thinking about natural disasters and I learned how to conduct good ethnographic data by reading the book assigned to the class. I learned the importance of analysis due to our final paper assignment. I also learned how to take good notes and the importance of key notes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the basics of anthropology and the ways to think about different problems from a more global perspective. I felt really pushed out of my comfort zone with my thinking, and really enjoyed that this class personally challenged me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think historically about science understanding that science is shaped by cultural, political, and social forces, not just facts or discoveries.I developed the skill of analyzing primary and secondary sources with historical context in mind, especially when reading texts from different time periods and regions.I gained new insight into how science has been used as a tool of power through empire, gender, and race and how that continues to shape the present.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the major paradigms for studying the history of science, including normal science/puzzle solving, scientific revolutions, and ideas about progress and its limits. This course covers the whole globe and many different disciplines, concepts, and periods of history, starting with early modern natural philosophy and going up to modern genetics, data science/computing, and pseudoscience. It's a good introduction to a lot of different topics and you talk about something very different pretty much every day.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course provides a unique connection between historical concepts and scientific theory. It really shows the interconnectedness of the two and the many stories that culminated in the modern day. It taught me many different ways of thinking about science, stretching from pseudoscience to centuries-old trees of knowledge. I forced me to think critically and also required a bit of recall in different disciplines such as biology and physics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the methods that are used to understand history from a second-hand perspective as well as a lot of facts about the development of science throughout history. I also learned about the development of science for industry and how the interplay between the two allowed for the advancement of science.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

The history of man’s intellect, 
The drawing of connections between scientific movements and paradigms throughout history,

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

3. How to compare different eras in the history of science and use primary source readings from different times as evidence

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the lectures and I think Prof Boucher does a great job making the long lectures entertaining and interesting. I enjoyed the discussion posts as I think they help students learn, think, and assess their own opinions on topics. I think my favorite part of the class was the group presentations. All the groups picked very interesting healthcare issues and I enjoyed getting to learn about some of the specific topics in our healthcare system that were not covered in class. I also appreciate not having a final. Having tests would change the dynamic of the class. The current structure allows for students to debate about topics, and really think about the endless list of healthcare issues our system has. Having a final or other test would change the dynamic into something that people have to memorize the information instead of analyzing and reflecting upon the topics.

response_text:

1) I learned about the current challenges facing policymakers and care providers, as well as the not-so easy potential solutions.

response_text: I think this is a fascinating course, I can really see how it's the starting point for the health policy certificate. It's a really fun and insightful class, but it can also be a bit draining too. It's sad to hear about policies actively working against providing universal health care access, and it's even worse to hear about specific issues we're too powerless to change. Regardless, this course was quite outstanding, both in its material and the professor, and I would certainly recommend it!

response_text: I'd highly recommend this class for anyone who may be interested in health policy or going into a health profession in the future (aka premeds- you should take this course)! The weekly reflections took me longer than I initially thought it would (3-5 hours, including reading the assigned articles + writing), but I learned so much.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.

response_text: This course was a great introduction to the US healthcare system, with complex topics and debates ranging from abortion to healthcare insurance coverage. We discussed the dominance of employer-sponsored insurance and US health spend compared globally. I would recommend the course to anyone interested in health policy, community health, and medicine!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned how biases present themselves in studies. I learned about the U.S. healthcare landscape and the many factors that have influenced its becoming.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to put my own personal beliefs aside and write objectively, even if I did not agree with the stance I was taking. I also learned about the various considerations that go into policy decisions and that it will be much more difficult to reform healthcare than I previous thought.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed an ability to critically weigh benefits and drawbacks of the American healthcare system, and to evaluate my ideas with sufficient rigor. The latter point was an emphasis of the class, which I greatly appreciated as I potentially consider a career in health policy.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Dr. Ubel's style of "cold calling" students in class helped me to think on me feet, stay engaged, allow my opinions and ideas to be challenged, and use critical thinking skills. Additionally, the "impossible to answer" essay prompts made me think more broadly and precisely.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think about the US healthcare system. We did this through readings, quizzes, and essays, as well as in class participation. I learned numerous insights into just how complicated the US healthcare system truly is, and how it converges with the field of economics. We studied cost, quality, and access extensively, and critically evaluated what aspects should be tackled in order to fix a flawed system.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the US healthcare system and its pros and cons. The essays make you question what you think is true and then decide how to best refute opposing views. I learned to be much more critical of what our current systems in place are and that even though the US is doing something does not make it the right thing to do. I also learned to concisely get points across, especially when the topics can be hard to discuss.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-- Knowledge about the basic structures of the US healthcare system, including private insurers, CMS, drug manufacturers/pharmacies/PBMs, etc. Some comparison to other countries
-- How incentives modify the behavior of patients, physicians, hospitals, insurers, and so on 
-- Various payment systemts, attempted reforms, and ongoing research into future models of health care

response_text: The smaller class size was nice because we could speak freely. I liked being able to jump in with questions, though cold calling could be a little nerve wracking. We also had readings due before every class which was nice because it helped give the class's discussion some basis when I did not know what we were talking about. Professor Ubel also tried to keep the class light with jokes (though his humor can be a little confusing) :)

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The cold-calling might have been controversial but I actually liked it. I think it helped the class stay engaged and made sure everyone contributed. The lectures were also engaging/informative/well-paced, and the class had an overall focus and central narrative that informed the topics we discussed. 
I also thought that the reading selection was strong, and the quizzes did a good job of helping me engage with the reading.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The major assignments are 1000 word essays that you write every other week and short weekly quizzes on the readings. Note that there is no in-class instruction on how to write the essays that they want, but you can do separate meetings. Also, you will likely need to do outside research to complete the essays.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: For a primer on the American healthcare system, including recent history and contemporary issues, this is a must-take course. Provides a vocabulary to intelligently discuss key health policy topics. Also, piques an interest in many topics that can then be explored in much more depth.

response_text: I would really recommend taking this course if you can. It is super interesting and really makes you question the US healthcare system. The essays and weekly quizzes could be a lot and the essays could be graded toughly, so put in effort for those. Overall a really good class!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
disability itself is a method
disability is a identity
why disability matters

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned to expand my definition of disability outside of the medical model, which is very essentialist.
Additionally, I was challenged to expand my definition of "care" and look critically at how these structures are often interconnected with lack of action by the state, and how this factors into disability studies. 
Finally, I learned about the words "disability" and "impairment" and how those in either community choose to use (or not use) these terms for specific reasons.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: practice of asking for what you need, the world is larger than the united states and how disability is understood or lived is very different, yet also how large systems debilitate people across the world; also the romanticization of care

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First, I learned how to critically read articles and conceptualize points of critique and agreement. Secondly, I learned about disability on a global sphere and moved outside of my prior United States context of disability. Lastly, I enjoyed my time learning about the politics, dialogue, and misconceptions surrounding care and caregiving.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. more expansive view of what may or may not be labeled as disability, and what the implications of doing so are
2. critiques of social and medical models of disability
3. politics of care and how neoliberalism affects who is responsible for care

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This is the first course I have taken in Disability Studies and it was, needless to say, a fantastic introduction. Emily was an incredible professor whose knowledge, passion, humor, and enthusiasm made the class wonderful. I learned a lot throughout the course including the general models of disability, the ways in which capitalism and work intersect with disability, and the extent to which disability appears and is recognized, understood, perceived, etc. in society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me about different models and ways of viewing disability, such as the social model. We also learned about the history of disability and how capitalism has played into understandings and definitions of what it means to be disabled. Finally, we learned to think about disability in ways that allow us to apply these frameworks to other situations in the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
My view of disability and the idea of how bodies are a part of societal systems related to work (and the toll taken on bodies as value is extracted from them) was novel, and changed my worldview in a lot of things. 
1. Neoliberalism and how it puts a focus on individuals 
2. How external conditions can cause disability (like gangs) 
3. Cultural/shared disability was very interesting, especially when in the context of the Gaza conflict

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the different models of disability, I learned about disability in relation to capitalism, and I learned how to critically evaluate ethnographies, historical texts, narratives/creative works, etc in the context of our class
